content: Be inquisitive. Know what you don't know.
Click on a post in the sidebar to view it. Click on a paragraph to view related ideas.

Look up here, I’m in heaven.content: I’m tickled you’re here reading this. I may not know you nor get feedback but that’s okay. I still have a chance to touch you in some way with what I share – what could be better than that!
I've been spending time gathering ideas in the [garden](https://ideas.jenett.org) – check it out and yeah, thanks for stopping by.

The web has changed but there remain remnants of what it once was in terms of personal sites. I track some of those remnants, curating such sites (which are still active, or when I’m lucky, new), hoping to somehow keep my original vision of the web intact. It’s a tough road to drive on but I’ve got a decent set of wheels with a few bells and whistles and more important, I enjoy the driving.

We lived above the sub shop. My parents had opened one of area’s first, specializing in [Italian subs](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#sub), Philly steak sandwiches, Sicilian pizza, and other goodies. It’s not surprising I was a fat little kid back then.
So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.
How ’bout the fact that I’m here to write this – another chance to capture ideas – my days are numbered. Your’s are too. There’s nothing more cliché than *that’s life*.

Decades ago, I was one of the giggling twins standing and jumping up and down on the passenger seat next to our mother who was driving the little Nash Rambler. I think we were about 3 years old at the time and this is the earliest memory I’ve managed to retain over the years.

I’ve got scars that can’t be seen.content: I want to deal with what’s possible, not wallow is what’s already taken place and left its ugly mark.

I can remember walking around the old neighborhood wondering what water temperature would be best for washing my hair. I also thought about whether or not I would ever have it cut again. It had grown quite long while I was in school and coming back to the neighborhood after almost four years was awkward for me to say the least. I needed to find a job quick. Living in that old house again on Royal Palm Avenue with my mother wasn't an option. I wouldn't have been able to handle that for very long and as it turned out, I didn't have to. Nor did I cut my hair.

I’ve got drama, can’t be stolen.content: I want to deal with what’s possible, not wallow is what’s already taken place and left its ugly mark.

In my life and especially on the web, I have this thing about keeping the personal and commercial stuff separate. Like anyone, I have a business side. No one can survive without taking care of business.
So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.

Everybody knows me now.content: and I know how to make one!
I’m tickled you’re here reading this. I may not know you nor get feedback but that’s okay. I still have a chance to touch you in some way with what I share – what could be better than that!
Be inquisitive. Know what you don't know.
40 years later, looking back, I realize that little has changed.
So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.

Look up here, man, I’m in danger.content: I want to deal with what’s possible, not wallow is what’s already taken place and left its ugly mark.
I’m tickled you’re here reading this. I may not know you nor get feedback but that’s okay. I still have a chance to touch you in some way with what I share – what could be better than that!
Be inquisitive. Know what you don't know.

I’m convinced the thought that fills my mind most of the time is just a complex of [reactions](reactions.md) to the strange world I’m living in. Creative [urges](urges-1.md) struggle to redirect my mind to what I don’t see, to what might be.
Then again, one's own experience or perspective might come into play here - I know - I’m kinda silly...
“When one part of America hurts, we all hurt.”

I’ve got nothing left to lose.content: - There are things I want to understand but never will and there are things I understand no one else would ever want to.
So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.

I’m so high it makes my brain whirl.content: I’m convinced the thought that fills my mind most of the time is just a complex of [reactions](reactions.md) to the strange world I’m living in. Creative [urges](urges-1.md) struggle to redirect my mind to what I don’t see, to what might be.
So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.

Ain’t that just like me.content: An odd example as if it was written by an angry misogynistic guy or something. I’m just saying...
How ’bout the fact that I’m here to write this – another chance to capture ideas – my days are numbered. Your’s are too. There’s nothing more cliché than *that’s life*.

By the time I got to New York.content: I can remember walking around the old neighborhood wondering what water temperature would be best for washing my hair. I also thought about whether or not I would ever have it cut again. It had grown quite long while I was in school and coming back to the neighborhood after almost four years was awkward for me to say the least. I needed to find a job quick. Living in that old house again on Royal Palm Avenue with my mother wasn't an option. I wouldn't have been able to handle that for very long and as it turned out, I didn't have to. Nor did I cut my hair.

We lived above the sub shop. My parents had opened one of area’s first, specializing in [Italian subs](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#sub), Philly steak sandwiches, Sicilian pizza, and other goodies. It’s not surprising I was a fat little kid back then.

It was an old step van and the passenger seat wasn’t anchored. As my father drove, the seat slid forward then back then forward again. What a ride! I’m [guessing](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#shatters) I was about 10 or 11-years-old then based on the fact that Tony was with us in the van. He was a guy my father helped to immigrate from Cuba (in 1959?). We were on the way to [the bay](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#the%20bay).

Decades ago, I was one of the giggling twins standing and jumping up and down on the passenger seat next to our mother who was driving the little Nash Rambler. I think we were about 3 years old at the time and this is the earliest memory I’ve managed to retain over the years.
So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.
There’s a number of other pleasant memories since then through the next 5 years or so but many moments in my youth thereafter were destined to become repressed memories as an adult.
40 years later, looking back, I realize that little has changed.

I was living like a king.content: I can remember walking around the old neighborhood wondering what water temperature would be best for washing my hair. I also thought about whether or not I would ever have it cut again. It had grown quite long while I was in school and coming back to the neighborhood after almost four years was awkward for me to say the least. I needed to find a job quick. Living in that old house again on Royal Palm Avenue with my mother wasn't an option. I wouldn't have been able to handle that for very long and as it turned out, I didn't have to. Nor did I cut my hair.

We lived above the sub shop. My parents had opened one of area’s first, specializing in [Italian subs](https://ideas.joejenett.com/#sub), Philly steak sandwiches, Sicilian pizza, and other goodies. It’s not surprising I was a fat little kid back then.

This way or no way.content: because of it being that way.
I want to deal with what’s possible, not wallow is what’s already taken place and left its ugly mark.
so what if we never realize
- There are things I want to understand but never will and there are things I understand no one else would ever want to.

You know, I’ll be free.content: So. Need to carry on and make the best of my time.
How ’bout the fact that I’m here to write this – another chance to capture ideas – my days are numbered. Your’s are too. There’s nothing more cliché than *that’s life*.
I want to deal with what’s possible, not wallow is what’s already taken place and left its ugly mark.
I’m tickled you’re here reading this. I may not know you nor get feedback but that’s okay. I still have a chance to touch you in some way with what I share – what could be better than that!
I think “the future of awesome” really means “not quite awesome yet.” 😎
